repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Third Programmatic Financial and
            Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Programmatic
            Financial and Public Sector Adjustment Loan (PFPSAL) Project
            for Turkey were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and  Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the experience
            of PFPSAL provides a number of insights that speak to four
            distinct issues: (i) the critical role of country
            leadership; (ii) the importance of bundling knowledge and
            lending in Banks operations; (iii) the appropriate balance
            of the Bank's focus on supporting design and
            implementation of a program; and (iv) the specifics of
            programs in crisis situations. A High degree of up-front
            political leadership, ownership of the strategy, and the
            program by the key ministries in the government, and
            consensus behind the program were important preconditions
            for the successful adoption and implementation of reforms
            especially in the case of public sector reforms. The link
            between lack of public finance transparency and financial
            sector vulnerability was key for the success of the program.
            This underscores the usefulness of designing PFPSAL as a
            multi-sector program. At the same time, as the experience
            with the differing pace of implementation of the two
            components under PFPSAL III shows, separation into different
            programs may be called for at some point in time. In a
            much-improved environment waiting for an appropriate timing
            for the privatization of state banks has probably resulted
            in greater revenues than anticipated or that will have been
            achieved in faster sales. The increased interest in the
            Turkish banking sector was most unexpected only two or three
            years before partly because at the depth of the crisis it is
            easy to underestimate the extent of the recovery. Therefore,
            a broader conclusion could be that, On designing a program
            in the midst of a crisis, flexibility is particularly
            important regarding policy measures that may have widely
            differing outcomes under different states of the economy.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Programmatic Financial and Public
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts were only modest. The approach of combining
            financial and public sector reforms into a single operation
            is well suited to the Turkish context at this stage. The
            combination provides important synergies, including in terms
            of ensuring consistency between fiscal adjustment, and the
            financing requirements of the bank restructuring program,
            and in demonstrating to investors that Turkey is tackling
            the core structural weaknesses underlying the country's
            chronic macroeconomic instability. However, urgency and
            complexity of the financial and public sector
            reforms-juxtaposed with real world constraints on the
            institutional capacity of the Turkish administration-argues
            for selectivity in determining core conditions, and
            flexibility with regards to the timetable for the
            implementation of specific reform measures. In order to
            tackle the complex policy, and institutional reforms that
            Turkey is undertaking, the programmatic design of these
            Programmatic Financial project operations, recognizes the
            need to sequence measures over time, while taking into
            account the uncertainties inherent in the crisis conditions
            that Turkey has faced since early 2001. The programmatic
            design allows for a reasonable degree of adaptability to
            unfolding events on the ground, while maintaining overall
            coherence, and direction of the reforms. Another lesson
            suggests that unless a realistic assessment of the
            institutional capacity constraints of counterpart agencies
            is factored into the program, the program will be vulnerable
            to constraints, likely to be a serious obstacle to program
            implementation. These capacity constraints can be
            alleviated, in part, through timely provision of well
            focused technical assistance.

            Assistance Strategy progress report, the Programmatic
            Financial and Public Sector Adjustment Loan, and the
            Agricultural Reform Implementation Project for Turkey.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Programmatic Financial and Public
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Financial and Public
            Sector Adjustment Loan (PFPSAL) Project, aims at supporting
            the Government's multi-year financial, and public
            sector reform program. While it is proposed that the PFPSAL
            project, will be followed by a second operation, key project
            priorities include, in the financial sector: an overhaul of
            the regulatory framework for banking activity; the
            institutional development of the new Bank Regulation and
            Supervision Agency; resolution of bank problems, and
            failures; and, state bank restructuring, and privatization.
            In the public sector, priorities call for: structural fiscal
            policies; public expenditure management; financial
            accountability, and public liability management; and, public
            sector governance. The PFPSAL will provide budgetary support
            to help finance the costs, arising from the crisis, and
            continue to fund the critical social programs. Although the
            project will restore confidence in the banking system, and
            in the Government's ability to sustain fiscal
            adjustments, numerous risks include, a potential loss of
            political consensus, and institutional weaknesses,
            aggravated by the macroeconomic risk, that interest rates
            will remain higher than estimated, which would affect the
            sustainability of the public debt, renewing instability.
            But, tight fiscal discipline, and investor confidence in
            Turkish sovereign debt instruments will be essential here,
            to far outweigh the risks.
